From this time the southern part of Britain (proxima pars Britanniae) may be con- sidered to have been reduced to the form of a province. Camulodunum was practically the capital. Succeeding governors did little to extend the Roman dominion. In ΑΛ). 61 the province was all but lost. The Iceni under Boudicea suddenly rose in rebellion‚ stormed

x Camulodunum and massacred its garrison. They were

however completely beaten by Suetonius Paulinus, the governor, and the southern Britons were effectu- ally reconquered while the northern were overawed. During the following years the country was gradually Romanised, and the colonies of Camulodunum, Veru- lamium and Londinium which had been destroyed in the insurrection of Boudicea recovered their position. Vespasian’s reign from A. D. 69 to 79, saw the work of conquest still further advanced under Cerialis and his successor Frontinus.
